headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Rep. McCarthy Resigning From Congress At End Of The Year; TX Woman With High-Risk Pregnancy Files Lawsuit To Get An Abortion; Time Names Taylor Swift Person Of The Year. Aired 11:30a-12p ET

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right, breaking news. Former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy will soon be a former member of Congress. Kevin McCarthy. He is resigning.Our Chief Capitol Hill Correspondent Manu Raju here with the news. Manu, what have you learned?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: The Republican majority. Down to 220 to 213 after we saw last week, George Santos expelled from the House narrowing the majority even further. And some other retirements coming next year could make it even more complicated for Mike Johnson, the new speaker, to push it out. But a huge moment for the GOP as the former Speaker of the House now going to become a former member at the end of this year. Kevin McCarthy announcing his resignation by year's end, John.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It's a remarkable turn of events. It is a dramatic fall. It is a Republican seat that Kevin McCarthy sits in. But until there is a special election to fill it, the margin that Republicans have in the House, razor, razor-thin after George Santos leaves in that district in Long Island too. So, truly, this will be an extraordinary few months we are about to witness in the U.S. Congress. Manu Raju, thank you very much for that. Kate?

utterances.speaker: KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: We also have more breaking news coming in right now. The Coast Guard has just released a rare and highly critical report acknowledging that it had "failed to keep our people safe." It is a direct result of CNN's investigation, which revealed Coast Guard leaders covered up damning information about sexual assaults and other misconduct for years. CNN's chief investigative correspondent Pamela Brown has much more on this.Lot of hard work has gotten to uncovering a lot of this, Pamela. What does this report now say?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. and, Pamela, is -- you've been listening out a lot of this happens stretching back decades.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: But these Coast Guard members say the problems still exist? BROWNNow next week, there'll be a hearing by the Senate Homeland Security Committee, and there's also an inspector general's investigation that has been ordered. We're just hearing from senators reacting to this report, including Senator Cantwell, who talked about that and expressed dismay that well it is good that the Coast Guard is trying to address these issues, there really is a lack of accountability looking backwards for those who were part of this culture of cover up at the Coast Guard with the sexual assault. And the fact the lack of justice for the victims. But Senator Cantwell for her part says that she is looking forward to the results of this inspector general report investigation that is currently underway. That investigation again, a direct result of CNN investigative teams reporting, Kate.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Pamela, thank you so much for bringing that to us and for your continued work and the team's work on this. Thank you. John.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: A woman living in Texas is now suing the state asking a court to declare that she has the right to terminate her pregnancy. Kate Cox says that she has a very high-risk pregnancy. At best, her doctors say her child is unlikely to live more than a few days outside the womb.And, she says, continuing the pregnancy is putting her own life at risk. That's why she now says that she is looking -- and why she is now looking to the court for help. She's 20 weeks pregnant and living in a state with a near-total ban on abortions. CNN's Whitney Wild joins us now. She's got more on this. Whitney, what more are you learning about this lawsuit?

utterances.speaker: WHITNEY WILD, CNN LAW ENFORCEMENT CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Kate, basically the crux of the lawsuit is that if she carries this pregnancy to term, she risks her own life or a possible catastrophic injury to her that would cause irreparable physical damage moving forward. And that, she says is actually one of the bars for the Texas abortion ban. So, the Texas abortion ban is banning abortions after six weeks unless there is risk to the life of the mother or a chance that carrying a pregnancy to term would cause irreversible physical damage to that person that would impair them long term. So, she says that she does qualify. However, she points out that that law is really vague. So, at this point, there was major concern among her doctors as well as her husband that if she goes through with an abortion, they face a legal risk because that's what the Texas law allows. It allows people to bring cases against other people who facilitate abortions.So, here's what's going on. Again, as you point out, she's 20 weeks. She's had these very severe complications. She's been to the emergency room three times with severe cramping with unidentifiable fluid leaks. This is she believes largely a result of her infant being diagnosed with an extra chromosome -- an extra 18th chromosome This is called Edwards syndrome. We have a graphic here that takes us through some of the facts of that. This is a very severe genetic condition. It caused -- it's caused, again by an extra chromosome 18. And at least 95 percent of cases, fetuses don't survive the full term. So, this is -- again, she believes that if she carries his baby to term, either the -- she's going to have to go through the absolute agony of her own very severe medical injury, the death of the baby in utero, or have to watch the baby die after it's born. Again, Kate, this is certainly a case to watch because it is the first that we know of where someone is trying to get a basically a court order to allow for an abortion. So, certainly, again a case to watch, Kate.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, sure is. Whitney, thank you very much for the reporting. John?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: In case you don't know who that is.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I don't, John. Who was that?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: OK. That is Taylor Swift.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, I have heard of her. I've heard of her.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Well, and I know I'm -- I am going to say out loud everyone is thinking who -- we knew that Harry Enten was the Taylor Swift expert.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I'm so glad.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Senior Taylor Swift expert.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: The see -- that's exactly right. But is Time's Person of the Year. John's telling him up and things that she's been on there now four times if you count --

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) You look at it.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: If you count -- if you counted Time Magazine.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, the silence breakers in 2017. She was on the cover for that.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And one of them, she wasn't born. I saw the one --

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: She was you -- she was part of You in 2006, which we all won.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Well, we all won.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, we won that.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And then -- and then in 1975, the American Room. She wasn't born yet.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: She and I were not born then.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: So, I don't think we can claim it. Though, I would like to. But by the numbers -- Time Magazine by the number.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I mean, normally, you know, presidents get a name or whatever, named about 23 times I think it was time person of the century, of course, was Albert Einstein. So -- Einstein, excuse me. So, the fact that she's now up with Albert Einstein as somebody who has graced the cover of Time, and she's actually done it more for personally, you're a person of the century, than he has.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: In this, like, football fans, it's become a thing.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: It's become a thing. I mean, record ratings for the Kansas City Chiefs on television. Kelce's podcast has gone through the roof. JERSEY sales.So, it's not just about her. She's a giver, too. She has given Travis Kelce their wonderful gift of fame.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And again, for people who don't like seeing her at the football game, she goes "I have no awareness of if I'm being shown too much, and pissing off a few dads, Brad's and Chaz."

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: She's made Harry very happy.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Best story real, quick. I never have enough time. My daughters were debating how mad they were that Taylor Swift was cheating on Travis Kelce. And I said, what are you talking about? They're like she says Karma is a boy -- is her boyfriend. Thinking the karma was a person.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And then we got into a long discussion about karma.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That was worth it.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: It was -- it was so funny.
